headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: I wanted to focus a little bit on the supply side of the market. I'm just wondering if any of your verticals or any of your geographies are starting to run up against any supply constraints?
componenttext: I wanted to focus a little bit on the supply side of the market. I'm just wondering if any of your verticals or any of your geographies are starting to run up against any supply constraints?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'd say, Jeff, clearly, technology would have the most supply issues. That said, I wouldn't put it in the chronic category. And if you look at the growth rate, I would not say it's overly growth constraining. Generally speaking, the better candidates acro
componenttext: I'd say, Jeff, clearly, technology would have the most supply issues. That said, I wouldn't put it in the chronic category. And if you look at the growth rate, I would not say it's overly growth constraining. Generally speaking, the better candidates across our lines of business still get multiple offers, they still get counteroffers from their current employers, particularly on the perm side. So while there are pockets of supply issues by  line of business, I don't think it rises overall that it's terribly growth constraining. We see job order flow is remaining steady. We see demand remaining solid. We would say that clients are getting a little more methodical with their hiring processes. The hiring process is a little bit slower, the sales cycle is a little bit longer. We're seeing some deceleration in our growth rates, even in the U.S. But it's deceleration against a very high growth rates and the growth rates that remain, were quite pleased with this environment. And I'll make a further environment issue. If you look at our revenues for this quarter, when the unemployment rate was 8.2%, you have to go back to 2006 to find similar revenues, and at that time, the unemployment rate was 4.5%. So we're quite happy that we can return to revenue levels in the U.S. where unemployment rates were 4.5% versus today, where unemployment rates are 8.2%. The point being, if we can ever get those unemployment rates down to a more normal recovery level, we think we can do significantly better.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: One other comment on the supply issue, the quality of candidates, as you might expect, is and has been for sometime, extremely high. And that's a function of course of the overall unemployment rate. But with the exception, Keith mentioned in certain areas
componenttext: One other comment on the supply issue, the quality of candidates, as you might expect, is and has been for sometime, extremely high. And that's a function of course of the overall unemployment rate. But with the exception, Keith mentioned in certain areas particularly technology, the quality of candidates is excellent.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: If I can stick just a few numbers questions. What share count is embedded in your third quarter guidance, what should we be using for CapEx for the year? And then jumping ahead to the fourth quarter, I'm not asking for guidance, but are there any billing
componenttext: If I can stick just a few numbers questions. What share count is embedded in your third quarter guidance, what should we be using for CapEx for the year? And then jumping ahead to the fourth quarter, I'm not asking for guidance, but are there any billing days issues between 4Q 2012 and 4Q 2011?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, share count won't change dramatically. Maybe it will be down a touch as we continue to buy stocks, which we've done consistently in the first couple of quarters. CapEx, we said 60 to 70 early in the year. I think year-to-date, we're at 24, 25, say a
componenttext: Okay, share count won't change dramatically. Maybe it will be down a touch as we continue to buy stocks, which we've done consistently in the first couple of quarters. CapEx, we said 60 to 70 early in the year. I think year-to-date, we're at 24, 25, say annualized, we're at 50. I think the 60-ish number still probably very reasonable so actually I wouldn't change the range versus we first gave you. As to billing days, Q4 '12, 62 days, Q4 '11, 61 days. So that day we lose in the third quarter, we get it back in the fourth.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Ginocchio from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Ginocchio from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just a question about health care reform. I know it's early to know that elections could change everything. But I think there's something within health care reform that if you have less than 50 employees, you're exempt from health reform or from the manda
componenttext: Just a question about health care reform. I know it's early to know that elections could change everything. But I think there's something within health care reform that if you have less than 50 employees, you're exempt from health reform or from the mandate. I'm just wondering what percentage of our clients have less than 50 clients? And do you think there could a potential pickup in demand from those as they try to keep the headcount below 50 to stay below the mandate? And how much -- do you try to maybe think about what the potential positive is for the business?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: While it's a theoretical potential positive, the sweet spot of our client size is more 75 to 100 employees rather than 50 or fewer. So while maybe some of that will happen in a good way, that's not something we've certainly dialed in. The 2 big issues on
componenttext: While it's a theoretical potential positive, the sweet spot of our client size is more 75 to 100 employees rather than 50 or fewer. So while maybe some of that will happen in a good way, that's not something we've certainly dialed in. The 2 big issues on health care reform, Paul, would be how do you define full-time employee for purposes of whose eligible comment; and further, how do you find minimum essential coverage. And the Treasury Department got some regulations out there that are out for comment. Those regulations aren't bad from the staffing industry's point of view. But how those regulations end up, nobody knows for sure at this time.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on the gross margin attempt. It looks like the year-on-year growth wasn't as good in the second quarter as the first. I don't know if I missed it, but was there -- even adjusting for the workers comp, sort of differentials this year versu
componenttext: Just a follow-up on the gross margin attempt. It looks like the year-on-year growth wasn't as good in the second quarter as the first. I don't know if I missed it, but was there -- even adjusting for the workers comp, sort of differentials this year versus last, the restatement or the add back, what was the driver there, if I missed it?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Clearly, there's an international zone impact on gross margin overall. As I said, we progressed nicely in the U.S. versus the first quarter. But the international zone gross margins, not unexpectedly, took somewhat of a hit during the second quarter.
componenttext: Clearly, there's an international zone impact on gross margin overall. As I said, we progressed nicely in the U.S. versus the first quarter. But the international zone gross margins, not unexpectedly, took somewhat of a hit during the second quarter.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Sara Gubins from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Sara Gubins from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just a question on the perm growth that you've done in the first 2 weeks of July, 37% is pretty impressive, particularly given what you're seeing in the second quarter. I know that's highly variable in 3 weeks a short period of a quarter. But could you ju
componenttext: Just a question on the perm growth that you've done in the first 2 weeks of July, 37% is pretty impressive, particularly given what you're seeing in the second quarter. I know that's highly variable in 3 weeks a short period of a quarter. But could you just talk about what you're seeing in the beginning of the quarter?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, as you know, perm is the most volatile week-to-week business we have. And to add to the irony of the post-quarter start, the international operations were stronger than U.S. and perm out of the gate. So while I don't want to totally discount the 37%
componenttext: Well, as you know, perm is the most volatile week-to-week business we have. And to add to the irony of the post-quarter start, the international operations were stronger than U.S. and perm out of the gate. So while I don't want to totally discount the 37% growth, I wouldn't place a huge amount of weight in it.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then it looks like total office counts was flat in the first half, is there any possibility of office consolidation in Europe?
componenttext: Okay. And then it looks like total office counts was flat in the first half, is there any possibility of office consolidation in Europe?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, we haven't changed our office count significantly in quite a number of years, unlike other general staffing firms, we have many fewer much larger locations. And for that reason, we tend not to open as many nor we do tend to close as many. So I don't
componenttext: Well, we haven't changed our office count significantly in quite a number of years, unlike other general staffing firms, we have many fewer much larger locations. And for that reason, we tend not to open as many nor we do tend to close as many. So I don't expect any significant office consolidation in Europe or anywhere else.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Gary Bisbee from Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Gary Bisbee from Barclays Capital.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: The question is on the Technology business. It continues to be very strong growth, but actually decelerated the growth rate same days consequence versus last quarter, more than some of the other segments given the strong demand and the shortages and all t
componenttext: The question is on the Technology business. It continues to be very strong growth, but actually decelerated the growth rate same days consequence versus last quarter, more than some of the other segments given the strong demand and the shortages and all that. Is that just you been growing so quickly that the comp issues or is there some softening within that business?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, it's primarily thair tougher comp, because frankly, if you look sequentially, the first quarter versus the second quarter on a real basis, technology actually had the highest growth rate, not the lowest. So if you're looking a year ago, technology w
componenttext: Well, it's primarily thair tougher comp, because frankly, if you look sequentially, the first quarter versus the second quarter on a real basis, technology actually had the highest growth rate, not the lowest. So if you're looking a year ago, technology was just knocking the cover off the ball with the growth rates, which made for much tougher comparisons. But actually in the second quarter just ended, our technology divisions had the highest sequential growth rates.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair point. And then I just wanted to given that you've continued to put up such a strong result and the stock really doesnt do a lot, do you ever consider be more aggressive share repurchases given the strong balance sheet is or you're very comf
componenttext: Okay, fair point. And then I just wanted to given that you've continued to put up such a strong result and the stock really doesnt do a lot, do you ever consider be more aggressive share repurchases given the strong balance sheet is or you're very comfortable with the consistent pace with which you've been pursuing that strategy over the last year or so?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think, history would say that we are comfortable with our consistent pace, the dollar cost average. So for the first 6 months of the year, our free cash flow was $86 million. Of that, we paid $42 million in dividends and our repurchases were $73 million
componenttext: I think, history would say that we are comfortable with our consistent pace, the dollar cost average. So for the first 6 months of the year, our free cash flow was $86 million. Of that, we paid $42 million in dividends and our repurchases were $73 million. so we're actually a little ahead of our cash flow, which is kind of our stated goal over time to spend our cash flow on dividends and repurchases.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Thomas Allen from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Thomas Allen from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Can you just update us on the regulatory front. There's obviously been a number of the government in Europe, anything that we should be keeping our eyes up for?
componenttext: Can you just update us on the regulatory front. There's obviously been a number of the government in Europe, anything that we should be keeping our eyes up for?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Nothing comes to mind in the U.S. There's been further discussion of IFRS. I think most word believe it's going to be a standard by standard adoption endorsement, such that there's not going to be that big bang one date everybody has to convert, but inste
componenttext: Nothing comes to mind in the U.S. There's been further discussion of IFRS. I think most word believe it's going to be a standard by standard adoption endorsement, such that there's not going to be that big bang one date everybody has to convert, but instead it's going to be a standard by standard conversion over time. When I actually think that'll be preferable. There's talk about mandatory audit quotation. There's talk about separation in Europe between external, internal audit. I mean, there are a lot of things in the year. I don't see anything that's going to have a huge short-term impact. We are starting to get a little more traction in Protiviti on Dodd-Frank. We actually have a couple of pretty significant Dodd-Frank readiness engagements. But some of Protiviti's larger financial institutions, so that's nice to see. But that's about it on the regulatory front.  We talked about health care earlier obviously.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then just follow-up opportunity. Obviously, results are improving there. How should we think about kind of the operating income trajectory there?
componenttext: And then just follow-up opportunity. Obviously, results are improving there. How should we think about kind of the operating income trajectory there?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: So the results are improving. They improved both in the U.S. and they actually improved a little bit in non-U.S. year-over-year. Quarter 3, particularly in the U.S., is usually Protiviti's strongest quarter. But quarter 3 outside the U.S. is impacted by A
componenttext: So the results are improving. They improved both in the U.S. and they actually improved a little bit in non-U.S. year-over-year. Quarter 3, particularly in the U.S., is usually Protiviti's strongest quarter. But quarter 3 outside the U.S. is impacted by August vacation holiday periods. But generally, quarter 3 is when Protiviti has its strongest operating margins of the year. We've talked before, our long-term objective which we remain optimistic about is that Protiviti can have consolidated double-digit margins. We're not there yet, but we're pleased with the U.S. margins which are expanding, and we think will expand further. And we are starting to see a little light at the end of the tunnel outside the U.S. That said, the market conditions in Europe aren't exactly the best they've ever been.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of James Samford from Citigroup.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of James Samford from Citigroup.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to touch on, I think you mentioned that the bill rates spread in the U.S. had been very strong, any color on what's going on the European side?
componenttext: I just wanted to touch on, I think you mentioned that the bill rates spread in the U.S. had been very strong, any color on what's going on the European side?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Clearly, there are more market challenges in Europe other than Germany than are the case in the United States. And you see some compression of pay bill spreads that was to be expected, we modeled it in. We expect a little more in the quarter that we're in
componenttext: Clearly, there are more market challenges in Europe other than Germany than are the case in the United States. And you see some compression of pay bill spreads that was to be expected, we modeled it in. We expect a little more in the quarter that we're in. So I don't think there's anything there out of what you would expect, given the market conditions.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Then the other sort of competitive dynamics sort of taking place in any particular countries?
componenttext: Then the other sort of competitive dynamics sort of taking place in any particular countries?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Competitive dynamics, there's no real changes in competitive dynamics, of note. Again, we are doing extremely well in Germany, not only in accounting finance, but in technology as well. We're very bullish on Germany. We continue to invest in headcount in
componenttext: Competitive dynamics, there's no real changes in competitive dynamics, of note. Again, we are doing extremely well in Germany, not only in accounting finance, but in technology as well. We're very bullish on Germany. We continue to invest in headcount in Germany. Germany is very profitable. The margins in Germany approach the margins in the United States, which we're very pleased with. So we could say more good things about Germany, competitively, I'm not sure the landscapes changed enough to comment on.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Tobey Sommer from SunTrust.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tobey Sommer from SunTrust.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Within the Technology business, I was wondering if you had domestic rates of growth for the staffing business? And if you could comment about whether the perm trends had a variance from the overall perm growth rates that you described?
componenttext: Within the Technology business, I was wondering if you had domestic rates of growth for the staffing business? And if you could comment about whether the perm trends had a variance from the overall perm growth rates that you described?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: So far as domestic growth rates for staffing technology, so we don't break out line of business between U.S. and non-U.S. The biggest non-U.S. tech operation we have is in Germany. So it's doing well and ramping up as we speak. As to perm versus temp inta
componenttext: So far as domestic growth rates for staffing technology, so we don't break out line of business between U.S. and non-U.S. The biggest non-U.S. tech operation we have is in Germany. So it's doing well and ramping up as we speak. As to perm versus temp intact, perm's actually doing a little better than temp, but they're both doing well. And we talked last time that perm tech is 18% to 20% of perm overall. So it's a little larger portion of the perm business then temp tech is of the temp business.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: You really don't describe the segment growth rates between global and domestic, is it fair based on the rates of sequential growth and year-over-year growth that you described for the tech business that the domestic piece must have been somehow above aver
componenttext: You really don't describe the segment growth rates between global and domestic, is it fair based on the rates of sequential growth and year-over-year growth that you described for the tech business that the domestic piece must have been somehow above average?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Above average. So on a sequential basis, tech grew the fastest of any of our lines of business. On a year-over-year basis, it was within 10 basis points of being the fastest there as well. So I don't think -- I mean, I can state, as supported by the sched
componenttext: Above average. So on a sequential basis, tech grew the fastest of any of our lines of business. On a year-over-year basis, it was within 10 basis points of being the fastest there as well. So I don't think -- I mean, I can state, as supported by the schedules that we put out there, that tech is the strongest part of our business, which is not surprising given the investments we've made.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Right. Thank you. Can you describe what your plans are for increasing recruiters staff? And any color you could give us across the different segments will be great.
componenttext: Right. Thank you. Can you describe what your plans are for increasing recruiters staff? And any color you could give us across the different segments will be great.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: So as to additions to staff, the general answer that applies to virtually all lines of business is that we expect to invest proportionate to what we expect the revenues to grow by. Where we don't expect the revenues to grow, which is some of the European
componenttext: So as to additions to staff, the general answer that applies to virtually all lines of business is that we expect to invest proportionate to what we expect the revenues to grow by. Where we don't expect the revenues to grow, which is some of the European countries, we would be on a headcount reduction mode. Where we do expect growth, we would expect to add heads at no greater rate than what we expect revenues to grow.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Kevin McVeigh from Macquarie.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Kevin McVeigh from Macquarie.

componenttext: Keith, can you just remind us, in terms of international, what percentage is kind of Germany versus Australia versus Canada versus Belgium today in terms of overall contribution?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. And so actually, I'll read this of to you but can also go to our website under our investors slides, and we have a couple of slides that have this data. So of the total 28% that's international, 13% of that's Europe, 6% is Canada, 5% is Asia-Pacific
componenttext: Sure. And so actually, I'll read this of to you but can also go to our website under our investors slides, and we have a couple of slides that have this data. So of the total 28% that's international, 13% of that's Europe, 6% is Canada, 5% is Asia-Pacific and 4% is the U.K. And that further, if you look at Europe, that 13% breaks down to 5% is Belgium, 4% is Germany, 3% is France and 1% is all other. But again, go to our  website, go to the investors slides, and we have a slides there that break out what I just told you.

componenttext: So perm tech is 18% to 20% of perm overall.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Can you let us know what your clients in Europe, particularly, are kind of signaling down the road, so for example, should we assume that the growth rate, even past the third quarter is going to be impacted for some time to come? Or do you have any sense
componenttext: Can you let us know what your clients in Europe, particularly, are kind of signaling down the road, so for example, should we assume that the growth rate, even past the third quarter is going to be impacted for some time to come? Or do you have any sense of when that could snap back?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, as you know, perm is the most volatile and hardest to reach trends. The fact that perm is still positive, and in fact, and even outside the U.S. as our supplemental schedules shows, grew twice as fast as temp for the quarter ended. I would say we're
componenttext: Well, as you know, perm is the most volatile and hardest to reach trends. The fact that perm is still positive, and in fact, and even outside the U.S. as our supplemental schedules shows, grew twice as fast as temp for the quarter ended. I would say we're pleased by -- do we expect that to moderate more? Yes we do. Is it in free fall? Absolutely not. Are our people more bullish than our overall guidance? They are indeed. So again, there's no steep cliff on the horizon that our people see or we see, but further deceleration just seems to be a prudent assumption on our part. And if you look at the trend line, the last several quarters on the supplemental sheet we've given you, you see that the rates of growth have decelerated. But they're still positive and they're actually greater than they are in the temp side.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: And Keith, did you say that if we take the litigation settlement or add it back pretax operating profit, that temp operating profit was 9.7% of revenues?
componenttext: And Keith, did you say that if we take the litigation settlement or add it back pretax operating profit, that temp operating profit was 9.7% of revenues?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: The -- I believe it's the overall staffing operating profit is 9.7. The temp, unadjusted, is 6.2; adjusted is 8.5, which is an improvement over the last many quarters on the temp side and overall.
componenttext: The -- I believe it's the overall staffing operating profit is 9.7. The temp, unadjusted, is 6.2; adjusted is 8.5, which is an improvement over the last many quarters on the temp side and overall.

componenttext: The SUTA increases that we talked about last quarter were expected to be 30 basis points over 2011 when all is said and done and when all the states reported they actually ended up a little bit less than that. But at this point, we're very pleased that we passed through the SUTA increases, and we don't have the rest yet when the rest of the year.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Hello, and welcome to the Robert Half International Second Quarter 2012 Conference Call. Our host for today's call are Mr. Max Messmer, Chairman and CEO of Robert Half International; and Mr. Keith Waddell, Vice Chairman, President and Chief Financial Offi
componenttext: Hello, and welcome to the Robert Half International Second Quarter 2012 Conference Call. Our host for today's call are Mr. Max Messmer, Chairman and CEO of Robert Half International; and Mr. Keith Waddell, Vice Chairman, President and Chief Financial Officer. Mr. Messmer, you may begin.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Hello, everyone, and thank you for joining us. Before we begin, we would like to remind you that comments made on today's call contain predictions, estimates and other forward-looking statements. These statements represent our current judgment of what the
componenttext:
Hello, everyone, and thank you for joining us. Before we begin, we would like to remind you that comments made on today's call contain predictions, estimates and other forward-looking statements. These statements represent our current judgment of what the future holds and include words such as forecast, estimate, project, expect, believe, guidance and similar expressions. We believe these remarks to be reasonable but would remind you that they are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from the forward-looking statements. We've described some of these risks and uncertainties in today's press release and in our SEC filings, including our 10-Ks, 10-Qs and today's 8-K. We assume no obligation to update the statements made on this call.
Now let's discuss the second quarter. Global revenues for the second quarter were $1.03 billion, an increase of 10% from the second quarter of 2011. Income per share was $0.32, up 28% from the second quarter of last year. Net income and income per share this quarter were reduced by $8.1 million, or $0.06 per share, related to a nonrecurring litigation settlement and the resolution of certain tax matters disclosed in our July 5, 2012, 8-K filing.
Cash flow from operations during the second quarter was $92 million. Capital expenditures were $14 million. We paid our stockholders a cash dividend of $0.15 per share at a cost of $21 million. We also repurchased 1.5 million RHI shares for a total of $43 million. There are approximately 3.6 million shares still available under our board-approved stock repurchase plan.
Demand for our specialized staffing and consulting services remains strong during the quarter, particularly in our U.S. staffing operations, which grew 17% versus the prior year. Gross margins continued to expand with an increasing mix of permanent placement and temp-to-hire conversion revenues.
Now I'll turn the call over to Keith Waddell for a more detailed review of our second quarter financial results.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Max. As you noted, second quarter revenues for the company were $1.03 billion, an increase of 10% over last year, or an increase of 1% sequentially. On a same-day constant currency basis, global staffing revenues increased 13% year-over-year, with
componenttext:
Thanks, Max. As you noted, second quarter revenues for the company were $1.03 billion, an increase of 10% over last year, or an increase of 1% sequentially. On a same-day constant currency basis, global staffing revenues increased 13% year-over-year, with the U.S. growing 17% and international locations growing 3% on this basis.
U.S. staffing revenues were $672 million in the second quarter of this year, while international staffing revenues for the quarter were $246 million. We have 353 staffing locations worldwide, including 103 locations in 19 countries outside the U.S.
We calculated 63.1 billing days in the second quarter compared to 63.3 days in last year's second quarter, and compared to 63.8 days in the first quarter of 2012. The lower number of billing days had the effect of reducing year-over-year staffing growth rates by 0.4% in the second quarter. The current quarter has 63.2 billing days.
Currency exchange rates reduced second quarter 2012 sequential revenues by $5 million and second quarter year-over-year revenues by $22 million. This had the effect of reducing year-over-year staffing growth rates by 2.4% in the second quarter.
Last quarter, we added a new supplemental schedule to the Investors' Center of our website at rhi.com. We have included a supplemental schedule again this quarter, both on our website and in our earnings press release. The schedule shows year-over-year revenue growth rates for each of our staffing lines of business on both a reported and also a same-day constant currency basis. It further splits the data between the U.S. and non-U.S. operations. Their information is presented for each of the 5 previous quarters. We've provided this information because we believe it better reflects our actual growth rates and aids in the evaluation of revenue trends over time. This information is considered to be a non-GAAP financial matter -- measure. Additional information, including a reconciliation of these growth rates to reported growth rates also is available on our website.
Second quarter revenues for Protiviti were $110 million, including $83 million in the United States and $27 million outside the U.S. Year-over-year growth rates were 5% globally, with U.S. revenue up 10% and non-U.S. revenue down 8%. Protiviti and its independently owned member firms serve clients through a network of 71 locations in 22 countries.
Now let's look at gross margin. Second quarter gross margin in our temporary and consulting staffing operations was 35.8% of applicable revenues. This was an 80-basis-point increase over the second quarter of last year and a 20-basis-points increase from the first quarter of 2012. The quarter-to-quarter increase relates primarily to higher temp-to-hire conversions, while the year-over-year increase relates primarily to higher pay/bill spreads. The most recent semiannual actuarial review of our workers' compensation reserves resulted in a second quarter credit of $400,000 compared to $1.3 million a year ago.
Perm placement revenue was 9.7% of staffing revenue for the quarter. Together with the higher temporary and consulting gross margins previously discussed, this resulted in an 80-basis-point increase in overall staffing gross margin compared to last year's second quarter. Protiviti's second quarter gross margin was $29 million, 26.4% of Protiviti revenue compared to $28 million or 26.9% of revenue a year ago.
Turning to selling, general and administrative cost. In the second quarter, our SG&A, cost and staffing were 34.4% of staffing revenues, including the nonrecurring charge of 2.1% of revenues related to the previously mentioned litigation settlement. Absent this charge, SG&A would have improved by 170 basis points from the prior year.
Second quarter SG&A costs for Protiviti were 24.6% of revenue. This was a 140-basis-point improvement from the prior year. Second quarter operating income from our staffing divisions was $70 million, or 7.6% of staffing revenues. This was reduced by 2.1% of revenues for the aforementioned litigation charge. The temporary and consulting divisions reported $52 million in operating income for the quarter, or 6.2% of applicable revenues.
Second quarter operating income for our permanent placement division was $18 million, or 20.6% of applicable revenues. Protiviti's operating profit was $2 million in the second quarter compared to $1 million in the second quarter a year ago. Accounts receivable were $532 million, with implied days outstanding of 47.1 days. This compares to 48.1 days at the end of the second quarter last year.
Now let's turn to third quarter guidance. We saw the following trends in the second quarter and the first few weeks of July: on a same-day constant currency basis, for our temporary and consulting staffing divisions, the year-over-year growth rates in April were about the same as March, then the growth rates gradually moderated in May and June; on a same-day constant currency basis for our permanent placement business, the year-over-year growth rates decelerated slightly in April, decelerated further in May and then were about the same in June as in May. During the first 2 weeks of July, revenues for our temporary and consulting businesses were up 8% on a same-day constant currency basis compared to the same period last year. For the first 3 weeks of July, permanent placement revenues were up 37% on a same-day constant currency basis compared to the same period last year. We would caution, however, it's difficult to evaluate trends over such short time periods.
Taking this information into account, we offer the following third quarter guidance: revenues, $1.01 billion to $1.06 billion; income per share, $0.36 to $0.41. It is our policy to limit guidance to one quarter. All estimates we provide on this call are subject to the risks mentioned in today's press release. Consistent with prior quarters, our guidance did not -- does not include any additional amounts for the settlement of outstanding legal claims.
Now I'll turn the call back over to Max.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Keith. As noted earlier on the call, we were pleased to see broad-based demand for our professional staffing and consulting services during the quarter. This is our eighth straight quarter of double-digit year-over-year revenue growth for the c
componenttext:
Thank you, Keith. As noted earlier on the call, we were pleased to see broad-based demand for our professional staffing and consulting services during the quarter. This is our eighth straight quarter of double-digit year-over-year revenue growth for the company on a same-day constant currency basis. Our results were strongest domestically, both within our staffing operations and Protiviti. Our growth rates outside the United States were not as strong, owing in large measure to ongoing concerns over the European debt crisis. Our business has limited exposure to the hardest-hit countries in Europe, but we did feel some of the effects of a more cautious business environment and lower currency exchange rates in Europe and other parts of the world. We continue to aggressively manage non-U.S. operating costs.
We remain encouraged by the trends we are seeing in the temporary staffing industry in the United States. Since March 2010, when nonfarm payrolls reached their lowest point in the current cycle, 17% of U.S. jobs created have been temporary ones versus 8% in the comparable period in the prior cycle. We believe skilled temporary professionals are becoming a permanent part of the human resources mix for a growing number of businesses.
Our Protiviti business also had a solid quarter, particularly in the United States, as a result of higher demand for its consulting services. Among other areas, Protiviti is benefiting from growth in IT-related consulting services, as well as its consulting business that specializes in the financial services industry.
At this time, Keith and I are happy to answer questions. Please limit yourself to 1 question and a single follow-up, as needed. If time permits, we will certainly try to return to you later in the call. Thank you.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Mark Marcon from Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Mark Marcon from Robert W. Baird.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about the trends that you're seeing in the U.S. I think in international markets, it's fairly obvious that the world is slowing down. But did you see any sort of deceleration in the U.S. over the course of th
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about the trends that you're seeing in the U.S. I think in international markets, it's fairly obvious that the world is slowing down. But did you see any sort of deceleration in the U.S. over the course of the quarter in the temp areas? And then secondly, can you speak to how you're thinking about investing, given the choppy nature of the headlines in terms of SG&A throughout the world?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, Mark. As to the U.S. trends, as we talk about in our formal remarks, there was a modest deceleration in our temp business in the U.S. as we went through the quarter. That deceleration continued post quarter, although we would caution that post quart
componenttext: Okay, Mark. As to the U.S. trends, as we talk about in our formal remarks, there was a modest deceleration in our temp business in the U.S. as we went through the quarter. That deceleration continued post quarter, although we would caution that post quarter is heavily impacted by Fourth of July, which, as you know, this year, fell on a Wednesday. Many of our clients took the whole week off. And so we're a little suspicious that the post-quarter numbers were overly impacted by Fourth of July. But again, it's hard to know that for sure. As to investing, we will continue to invest in tech, both in the U.S. and in Germany. That continues to do quite well. And we'll also continue to invest in perm, consistent with the revenue gains that we see, but pretty much in line with the revenue gains that we see.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Right. And then just a clarification, the legal settlement, did that all fall into the temp SG&A?
componenttext: Right. And then just a clarification, the legal settlement, did that all fall into the temp SG&A?

componenttextpreview: The legal settlement is 100% in the temp SG&A. The pretax amount is $19 million.
componenttext: The legal settlement is 100% in the temp SG&A. The pretax amount is $19 million.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. I just want to ask about the perm margins, which were much better than I would have expected, given the slowdown. Just how aggressively did you pull back on that, I guess particularly internationally? And is the productivity levels there so high now
componenttext: Yes. I just want to ask about the perm margins, which were much better than I would have expected, given the slowdown. Just how aggressively did you pull back on that, I guess particularly internationally? And is the productivity levels there so high now that you'll have to start to invest in it to get future growth? Is there still productivity opportunity in that business?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, we did expand our perm margins nicely during the quarter, as you note. As we stated on the last call, we pulled back our headcounts in Europe, particularly in countries that were the most impacted. We're quite pleased with our ability to adjust our
componenttext: Well, we did expand our perm margins nicely during the quarter, as you note. As we stated on the last call, we pulled back our headcounts in Europe, particularly in countries that were the most impacted. We're quite pleased with our ability to adjust our cost structure outside the U.S. during the quarter. We do not feel our perm margins are unsustainably high, and we'll continue to be vigilant with our headcount and our cost investments, particularly outside the U.S., with the exception of Germany as we go forward.

componenttext: Okay. And then just a numbers question from me. The tax rate here, if I adjust out for that chart, it seems like it was maybe 41.5 on a more normalized basis, which is turning back up. Is that just the shift in earnings between the U.S. and international? So should we assume?

componenttext: Right. That's precisely the case and go-forward assumption. Whereas before, we were 40 to down a bit, I would now say we're 40 to up a bit, let's call it 40 to 41.

componenttext: Keith, did you say something about, when looking at flex gross margins sequentially, that was driven by temp-to-hire conversion year-over-year by spread. My question is, is there any pause in the company's pricing power? How is the kind of spread environment looking in the second quarter?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: So the sequential improvement was conversions that, while improved by 20 basis points, are still at the low end of the traditional range. So we still feel like there's plenty of upside there. As to pricing power, we certainly don't see any pause in that.
componenttext: So the sequential improvement was conversions that, while improved by 20 basis points, are still at the low end of the traditional range. So we still feel like there's plenty of upside there. As to pricing power, we certainly don't see any pause in that. The actual bill rate changes for the quarter were 1.2% year-over-year, and that compares to 3.4% year-over-year last quarter. That decline is heavily impacted by non-U.S. operations. U.S. operations continue to get nice year-over-year bill rate increases.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: And how will flex gross margin look going into the third quarter?
componenttext: And how will flex gross margin look going into the third quarter?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our modeling for our guidance, and we'll talk a little bit more about that in just a second, given the somewhat volatile nature of conversions or temp-to-hire conversions, our guidance has flattish flex gross margins, to use your term, embedded in it. Let
componenttext: Our modeling for our guidance, and we'll talk a little bit more about that in just a second, given the somewhat volatile nature of conversions or temp-to-hire conversions, our guidance has flattish flex gross margins, to use your term, embedded in it. Let's talk a little bit about guidance generally. While on a reported basis, the range which show growth rates of 3% to 8% between low and high, if you adjust that for currency and days, that would instead be 7% to 12%. The 12% being real close to the 13% we just reported for the second quarter, the 7% at the low end being just less than the post-quarter start we got, which we're hoping was July 4-impacted. The third quarter will be more impacted by currency and be more impacted by days than was the second quarter. As to currency, the biggest impact is in the euro. A year ago, the euro was $1.41. The current euro is at $1.21. We think the currency will probably have 3 growth-rate points impact in the third quarter. Further, on the days, we'll have 1 fewer day in the third quarter than the third quarter a year ago, which will impact the growth rate by 1.5 points. So whereas in the second quarter just ended, there was about a 3-point differential between reported growth and real growth, which is constant currency same-day. In the third quarter, we think there'll be a 4- or 5-point differential between the real growth and reported growth.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: So first of all, let's talk a little bit about country composition. So our strongest country by leaps and bounds was Germany, which will be no surprise. And kind of in order, we still had positive growth in Australia, we still had positive growth in Canad
componenttext: So first of all, let's talk a little bit about country composition. So our strongest country by leaps and bounds was Germany, which will be no surprise. And kind of in order, we still had positive growth in Australia, we still had positive growth in Canada. We were slightly negative in Belgium. We were a little more negative in France, and we were the most negative in the U.K, although I'll add that the U.K. had slightly more operating income than a year ago, notwithstanding the revenues for which we congratulate them. As to trends, if you look at our supplemental schedule and you look at the international trend lines, I think you can pretty easily see that it would not be unexpected to see the year-over-year growth rates in the international region to go negative during the quarter, and our guidance is assumed as such.

componenttext: Okay, great. Can you took a bit more about the U.K. and, I guess, why that's so weak? Is it financial services-related? Or...

componenttextpreview: Well, I'd say there's 2 things going on there. The industry has been more challenged there for a while. In addition to that, we've walked away from really low-margin business, which exacerbate the revenue change. But as I said, if you look at the operatin
componenttext: Well, I'd say there's 2 things going on there. The industry has been more challenged there for a while. In addition to that, we've walked away from really low-margin business, which exacerbate the revenue change. But as I said, if you look at the operating income line, they're actually up year-over-year, and we're quite pleased with that.

componenttext: Okay, great. Could I ask about SG&A? We can back into it from what you just said about gross margin. But just kind of higher level, should we expect that to actually start to decline, given some of the things you talked about or ratchet up over time over the next few quarters?

componenttext: As a percent of revenue, given the range we gave for guidance, I wouldn't see it changing that much. If you look at the operating income line for staffing, the last few quarters have been 8%, 9%. We just did 9.7% adjusted for the charges. So we're quite pleased with the way our staffing operating income is progressing. And we would hope to stay on that trajectory, given particularly the top end of our guidance range.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: I wanted to focus a little bit on the supply side of the market. I'm just wondering if any of your verticals or any of your geographies are starting to run up against any supply constraints?
componenttext: I wanted to focus a little bit on the supply side of the market. I'm just wondering if any of your verticals or any of your geographies are starting to run up against any supply constraints?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'd say, Jeff, clearly, technology would have the most supply issues. That said, I wouldn't put it in the chronic category. And if you'd look at the growth rates, I would not say it's overly growth-constraining. Generally speaking, the better candidates a
componenttext: I'd say, Jeff, clearly, technology would have the most supply issues. That said, I wouldn't put it in the chronic category. And if you'd look at the growth rates, I would not say it's overly growth-constraining. Generally speaking, the better candidates across our lines of business still get multiple offers. They still get counteroffers from their current employers, particularly on the perm side. So while there are pockets of supply issues by line of business, I don't think it rises overall that it's terribly growth-constraining. We see -- job order flow is remaining steady. We see demand remaining solid. We would say that clients are getting a little more methodical with their hiring processes. The hiring process is a little bit slower, the sales cycle is a little bit longer. We're seeing some deceleration in our growth rates, even in the U.S., but it's deceleration against very high growth rates. And the growth rates that remain, we're quite pleased with in this environment. And I'll make a further environmental issue. If you look at our revenues for this quarter when the unemployment rate was 8.2%, you have to go back to 2006 to find similar revenues. And at that time, the unemployment rate was 4.5%. So we're quite happy that we could return to revenue levels in the U.S. where unemployment rates were 4.5% versus today, where unemployment rates are 8.2%. The point being, if we can ever get those unemployment rates down to a more normal recovery level, we think we can do significantly better.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: One other comment on the supply issue, the quality of candidates, as you might expect, is and has been for sometime extremely high. And that's a function of course of the overall unemployment rate. But subject to the exceptions Keith mentioned in certain
componenttext: One other comment on the supply issue, the quality of candidates, as you might expect, is and has been for sometime extremely high. And that's a function of course of the overall unemployment rate. But subject to the exceptions Keith mentioned in certain areas, particularly technology, the quality of candidates is excellent.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012

componenttext: All right, that's very helpful. if I can sneak in just a few numbers questions, what share count is embedded in your third quarter guidance? What should we be using for CapEx for the year? And then jumping ahead to the fourth quarter, I'm not asking you for guidance, but are there any billing days issues between 4Q 2012 and 4Q 2011?

componenttext: Okay, share count won't change dramatically. Maybe it'll be down a touch as we continue to buy stock, which we've done consistently in the first couple of quarters. CapEx, we said 60 to 70 early in the year. I think, year-to-date, we're at 24, 25, say annualized, we're at 50. I think the 60-ish number is still probably very reasonable. So actually, I wouldn't change the range versus what we first gave you. As to billing days, Q4 '12, 62 days; Q4 '11, 61 days. So that day we lose in the third quarter, we get it back in the fourth.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just a question about the health care reform. I know it's early to know, the elections could change everything, but I think there's something within the health care reform that if you have less than 50 employees, you're exempt from health reform or from t
componenttext: Just a question about the health care reform. I know it's early to know, the elections could change everything, but I think there's something within the health care reform that if you have less than 50 employees, you're exempt from health reform or from the mandate. I just wondered what percentage of our clients have less than 50 clients? And do you think there could be a potential pickup in demand from those as they try to keep their headcount below 50 to stay below the mandate? And how much -- do you have -- maybe try to think about what the potential positive is for your business.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, while it's a theoretical potential positive, I mean, the sweet spot of our client size is more 75 to 100 employees rather than 50 or fewer. So while maybe some of that will happen in a good way, that's not something we've certainly dialed in. The 2
componenttext: Well, while it's a theoretical potential positive, I mean, the sweet spot of our client size is more 75 to 100 employees rather than 50 or fewer. So while maybe some of that will happen in a good way, that's not something we've certainly dialed in. The 2 big issues on health care reform, Paul, would be how do you define full-time employees for purposes of who's eligible? And further, how do you define minimum essential coverage? And the Treasury Department's got some regulations out there that are out for comment. Those regulations aren't bad from the staffing industry's point of view. But how those regulations end up, nobody knows for sure at this time.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012

componenttext: As a follow-up on the gross margin attempt, it looks like the year-on-year growth wasn't as good in the second quarter as the first. I don't know if I missed it, but was there -- even adjusting for the workers' comp sort of differential this year versus last, the restatement or the add back, what was the driver there, if I missed it?

componenttext: Well, clearly there's an international zone impact on gross margins overall. As I said, we progressed nicely in the U.S. versus the first quarter. But the international zone gross margins, not unexpectedly, took somewhat of a hit during the second quarter.

componenttext: Just a question on the perm growth that you saw in the first 2 weeks of July. 37% is pretty impressive, particularly given what you were seeing in the second quarter. I know that's highly variable, and 3 weeks is a short period of the quarter. But were you -- could you just talk about what you were seeing in the beginning of the quarter?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, as you know, perm is the most volatile week-to-week business we have. And to add to the irony of the post-quarter start, the international operations were stronger than U.S. and perm out of the gate. So while I don't want to totally discount the 37%
componenttext: Well, as you know, perm is the most volatile week-to-week business we have. And to add to the irony of the post-quarter start, the international operations were stronger than U.S. and perm out of the gate. So while I don't want to totally discount the 37% growth, I wouldn't place a huge amount of weight in it.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then it looks like total office count was flat in the first half. Is there any possibility of office consolidation in Europe?
componenttext: Okay. And then it looks like total office count was flat in the first half. Is there any possibility of office consolidation in Europe?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, we haven't changed our office count significantly in quite a number of years. Unlike other general staffing firms, we have many fewer much larger locations. And for that reason, we tend not to open as many, nor do we tend to close as many. So I don'
componenttext: Well, we haven't changed our office count significantly in quite a number of years. Unlike other general staffing firms, we have many fewer much larger locations. And for that reason, we tend not to open as many, nor do we tend to close as many. So I don't expect any significant office consolidations in Europe or anywhere else.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Gary Bisbee from Barclays Capital.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: The question is on the Robert Half Technology business. It continues to be very strong growth, but it actually decelerated the growth rate, same-day constant currency growth rate versus last quarter, more than some of the other segments, given the strong
componenttext: The question is on the Robert Half Technology business. It continues to be very strong growth, but it actually decelerated the growth rate, same-day constant currency growth rate versus last quarter, more than some of the other segments, given the strong demand and shortages and all of that. Is that just that it had been growing so quickly that it's a tougher comps issue? Or is there some softening within that business?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, it's primarily their tougher comps, because frankly, if you look sequentially, the first quarter versus the second quarter on a real basis, technology actually had the highest growth rate, not the lowest. And so if you're looking a year ago, technol
componenttext: Well, it's primarily their tougher comps, because frankly, if you look sequentially, the first quarter versus the second quarter on a real basis, technology actually had the highest growth rate, not the lowest. And so if you're looking a year ago, technology was just knocking the cover off the ball with the growth rates, which made for much tougher comparisons. But actually, in the second quarter just ended, our technology divisions had the highest sequential growth rates.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair point. And then I just wanted to probe. Given that you continue to put up such strong results and the stock really doesnt do a lot, do you ever consider being more aggressive with share repurchases given how strong the balance sheet is? Or y
componenttext: Okay, fair point. And then I just wanted to probe. Given that you continue to put up such strong results and the stock really doesnt do a lot, do you ever consider being more aggressive with share repurchases given how strong the balance sheet is? Or you're very comfortable with the sort of consistent pace with which you've been pursuing that strategy over the last year or so?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, I think history would say that we're comfortable with our consistent pace, the dollar cost average. So for the first 6 months of the year, our free cash flow was $86 million. Of that, we paid $42 million in dividends, and our repurchases were $73 mi
componenttext: Well, I think history would say that we're comfortable with our consistent pace, the dollar cost average. So for the first 6 months of the year, our free cash flow was $86 million. Of that, we paid $42 million in dividends, and our repurchases were $73 million. So we're actually a little ahead of our cash flow, which is kind of our stated goal over time to spend our cash flow on dividends and repurchases.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Thomas Allen from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Can you just give us an update on the regulatory front? There's obviously been a number of changes with government in Europe. Anything that we should be keeping our eyes out for?
componenttext: Can you just give us an update on the regulatory front? There's obviously been a number of changes with government in Europe. Anything that we should be keeping our eyes out for?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Nothing comes to mind in the U.S. There's been further discussion of IFRS. I think most pundits believe it's going to be a standard-by-standard adoption/endorsement, such that there's not going to be the big bang, one date, everybody has to convert, but i
componenttext: Nothing comes to mind in the U.S. There's been further discussion of IFRS. I think most pundits believe it's going to be a standard-by-standard adoption/endorsement, such that there's not going to be the big bang, one date, everybody has to convert, but instead it's going to be a standard-by-standard conversion over time when -- I actually think that'd be preferable. There's talk about mandatory audit rotation. There's talk about separation in Europe between external/internal audit. I mean, there are a lot of things in the year. I don't see anything that's going to have a huge short-term impact. We are starting to get a little more traction in Protiviti on Dodd-Frank. We actually have a couple of pretty significant Dodd-Frank readiness engagements with some of Protiviti's larger financial institutions. So that's nice to see. But that's about it on the regulatory front. We talked about health care earlier, obviously.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. And then just following up on Protiviti, obviously, results are improving there. How should we think about kind of the operating income and trajectory there?
componenttext: Yes. And then just following up on Protiviti, obviously, results are improving there. How should we think about kind of the operating income and trajectory there?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: So the results are improving. They improved both in the U.S., and they actually improved a little bit non-U.S. year-over-year. Quarter 3, particularly in the U.S., is usually Protiviti's strongest quarter, but quarter 3 outside the U.S. is impacted by Aug
componenttext: So the results are improving. They improved both in the U.S., and they actually improved a little bit non-U.S. year-over-year. Quarter 3, particularly in the U.S., is usually Protiviti's strongest quarter, but quarter 3 outside the U.S. is impacted by August vacation holiday periods. But generally, quarter 3 is when Protiviti has its strongest operating margins of the year. We've talked before, our long-term objective, which we remain optimistic about is that Protiviti can have consolidated double-digit margins. We're not there yet, but we're pleased with the U.S. margins, which are expanding, and we think will expand further. And we're starting to see a little light at the end of the tunnel outside the U.S. That said, the market conditions in Europe aren't exactly the best they've ever been.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012

componenttext: Just wanted to touch on -- I think you mentioned that the bill rates spread in the U.S. were strong. Any color on what's going on, on the European side?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Clearly, there are more market challenges in Europe, other than Germany, than are the case in the United States. And you see some compression of pay/bill spreads. That was to be expected. We modeled it in. We expect a little more in the quarter that we're
componenttext: Clearly, there are more market challenges in Europe, other than Germany, than are the case in the United States. And you see some compression of pay/bill spreads. That was to be expected. We modeled it in. We expect a little more in the quarter that we're in. So I don't think there's anything there out of what you would expect, given the market conditions.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012

componenttext: And any other sort of competitive dynamics that are taking place in any of the particular countries?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Competitive dynamics? There's no real changes in competitive dynamics of note. Again, we're doing extremely well in Germany, not only in accounting finance, but in technology as well. We're very bullish on Germany. We continue to invest in headcount in Ge
componenttext: Competitive dynamics? There's no real changes in competitive dynamics of note. Again, we're doing extremely well in Germany, not only in accounting finance, but in technology as well. We're very bullish on Germany. We continue to invest in headcount in Germany. Germany is very profitable. The margins in Germany approach the margins in the United States, which we're very pleased with. So we couldn't say more good things about Germany. But competitively, I'm not sure the landscape's changed enough to comment on.

componenttext: So far as domestic growth rates for staffing technology, so we don't break out line of business between U.S. and non-U.S. The biggest non-U.S. tech operation we have is in Germany. So it's doing well and ramping up as we speak. As to perm versus temp in tech, perm actually is doing a little better than temp, but they're both doing well. And we talked last time that perm tech is 18% to 20% of perm overall. So it's a little larger portion of the perm business than temp tech is of the temp business.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012

componenttext: Even though you don't describe the segment growth rates between global and domestic, is it fair, based on the rates of sequential growth and year-over-year growth that you've described for the tech business, that the domestic piece must have been somehow above average?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Above average. So on a sequential basis, tech grew the fastest of any of our lines of business. On a year-over-year basis, it was within 10 basis points of being the fastest there as well. So I don't think -- I mean, I can state -- as supported by the sch
componenttext: Above average. So on a sequential basis, tech grew the fastest of any of our lines of business. On a year-over-year basis, it was within 10 basis points of being the fastest there as well. So I don't think -- I mean, I can state -- as supported by the schedules that will be put out there, the tech is the strongest part of our business, which is not surprising given the investments we've made.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Could you describe what your plans are for increasing recruiter staff? And any color you could give us across the different segments will be great.
componenttext: Could you describe what your plans are for increasing recruiter staff? And any color you could give us across the different segments will be great.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: So as to additions to staff, the general answer that applies to virtually all lines of business is that we expect to invest proportionate to what we expect the revenues to grow by. Where we don't expect the revenues to grow, which is some of the European
componenttext: So as to additions to staff, the general answer that applies to virtually all lines of business is that we expect to invest proportionate to what we expect the revenues to grow by. Where we don't expect the revenues to grow, which is some of the European countries, we would be in a headcount reduction mode. Where we do expect growth, we would expect to add heads at no greater rate than what we expect revenues to grow.

componenttext: Can you let us know what your clients in Europe, particularly, are kind of signaling down the road? So for example, should we assume that the growth rate, even past the third quarter, is going to be impacted for some time to come? Or do you have any sense when that could snap back?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 24, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, as you know, perm is the most volatile and hardest to read trends. The fact that perm is still positive -- and in fact, even outside the U.S., as our supplemental schedule shows, grew twice as fast as temp for the quarter ended. I would say we're pl
componenttext: Well, as you know, perm is the most volatile and hardest to read trends. The fact that perm is still positive -- and in fact, even outside the U.S., as our supplemental schedule shows, grew twice as fast as temp for the quarter ended. I would say we're pleased by -- do we expect that to moderate more? Yes we do. Is it in free fall? Absolutely not. Are our people more bullish than our overall guidance? They are indeed. So again, there's no steep cliff on the horizon that our people see or we see, but further deceleration just seems to be a prudent assumption on our part. And if you look at the trend line, the last several quarters on the supplemental sheet we've given you, you see that the rates of growth have decelerated. But they're still positive, and they're actually greater than they are on the temp side.
